article.title: Camelopardalis
article.paragraph:
Use dmy datesJuly 2012Infobox ConstellationCamelopardalis Cam{{sfn|Ridpath|2001|ppCamelopardalis{{sfn|Ridpath|2001|pp{{IPAc-en|k|ə|ˌ|m|ɛ|l|ə|ˈ|p|ɑr|d|əl|ɨ|s}}, genitive the same [[Giraffe]]{{sfn|Ridpath|2001|pp{{RA|03|15|36.2232}}–{{RA|14|27|07.8855}}<ref name{{dec|86.0975418}}–{{dec|52.6655540}}<ref name[[Ursa Major Family|Ursa Major]] 757 18th 2, 8 36 4 0 3 [[Beta Camelopardalis|β Cam]] 4.03 [[Gliese 445|LHS 2459]] 17.58 5.39 0 [[October Camelopardalids]] [[Draco (constellation)|Draco]]

[[Cepheus (constellation)|Cepheus]]

[[Ursa Major]] [[North Pole|90]] [[10th parallel south|10]] February CamelopardalisIPAc-enkəˌmɛləˈpɑrdəlɨsorthe Giraffeconstellationis a large, faint grouping of stars in thecelestial spherenorthern sky. The constellation was introduced in 1612 (or 1613) byPetrus Plancius. Some older astronomy books give an alternative spelling of the name,Camelopardus.sfnRidpath200192-93
article.heading: Etymology
article.paragraph: First attested in English in 1785, the wordcamelopardaliscomes fromLatin,cite webhttp://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doccamelopardalisLewisCharlton T.ShortCharlesA Latin DictionaryPerseus Digital Library8 June 2012and it is theromanisationof theGreek languageGreek"" meaning "giraffe",cite webhttp://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?docκαμηλοπάρδαλις Henry GeorgeLiddellRobertScottA Greek-English LexiconPerseus Digital Library8 June 2012from "" (kamlos), "camel"cite webhttp://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?docκάμηλοςHenry GeorgeLiddellRobertScottA Greek-English LexiconPerseus Digital Library8 June 2012+ "" (pardalis), "leopard",cite webhttp://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?docπάρδαλιςHenry GeorgeLiddellRobertScottA Greek-English LexiconPerseus Digital Library8 June 2012due to its having a long neck like a camel and spots like a leopard.
article.heading: Notable features

link.part: The constellation Camelopardalis as it can be seen by the naked eye.

article.heading: Stars
article.paragraph: Although Camelopardalis is the 18th largest constellation, it is not a particularly bright constellation, as the brightest stars are only of fourth magnitude. In fact, it only contains four stars above magnitude 5.0.sfnStaal1988241

list.listitem: Alpha CamelopardalisCamis a blue-hued supergiant star of magnitude 4.3, 5000 light-years from Earth. It is one of the most distant stars easily visible with the naked eye.sfnRidpath200192-93

Beta CamelopardalisCamis the brightest star in Camelopardalis with anapparent magnitudeof 4.03. This star is adouble star, with components of magnitudes 4.0sfnNorton1973118and 8.6. The primary is a yellow-hued supergiant 1000 light-years from Earth.sfnRidpath200192-93

11 Camelopardalis11 Camis a star of magnitude 5.2, 650 light-years from Earth. It is very close to magnitude 6.112 Camelopardalis12 Cam, also 650 light-years from Earth, but the two stars are not a true double star because of their separation.sfnRidpath200192-93

Struve 16941694(Struve 1694, 32 Cam)is abinary star300 light-years from Earth. Both components have a blue-white hue; the primary is of magnitude 5.4 and the secondary is of magnitude 5.9.sfnRidpath200192-93

CS CamelopardalisCS Camis the second brightest star, though it has neither aBayer designationBayernor aFlamsteed designation. It is of magnitude 4.21 and is slightlyvariable starvariable.sfnNorton1973118
Z CamelopardalisZ Camis frequently observed as part of a program ofAAVSO.American Association of Variable Star ObserversIt is the prototype ofZ Camelopardalis variable stars.

article.paragraph: Other variable stars areU Camelopardalis,VZ Camelopardalis, andMira variablesT Camelopardalis,X Camelopardalis, andR Camelopardalis.sfnNorton1973118RU Camelopardalisis one of the brighterType II Cepheidsvisible in the night sky.

In 2011 a supernova was discovered in the constellation.cite journalhttp://www.popsci.com/science/article/2011-01/10-year-old-canadian-girl-youngest-discover-supernova10-Year-Old Canadian Girl Is The Youngest Person Ever to Discover a SupernovaBoyleRebecca8 June 2012Popular Science3 January 2011
article.heading: Deep-sky objects
article.paragraph: Camelopardalis is in the part of thecelestial spherefacing away from thegalactic plane. Accordingly, many distant galaxies are visible within its borders.NGC 2403is a galaxy in theM81 groupof galaxies, located approximately 12 million light-years from EarthsfnWilkinsDunn2006sfnRidpath200192-93with a redshift of 0.00043. It is classified as being between anelliptical galaxyellipticaland aspiral galaxybecause it has faint arms and a large central bulge. NGC 2403 was first discovered by the 18th century astronomerWilliam Herschel, who was working in England at the time.sfnWilkinsDunn2006It has anintegrated magnitudeof 8.0 and is approximately 0.25 long.sfnRidpath200192-93

NGC 1502is a magnitude 6.9open clusterabout 3,000light yearsfrom Earth. It has about 45 bright members, and features a double star of magnitude 7.0 at its center.Revised NGC/IC Data 2013. Dr. Wolfgang Steinicke.NGC 1502 is also associated withKemble's Cascade, a simple but beautiful asterism appearing in the sky as a chain of stars 2.5 long that is parallel to the Milky Way and is pointed towardsCassiopeia (constellation)Cassiopeia.sfnRidpath200192-93NGC 1501is a planetary nebula located roughly 1.4 south of NGC 1502.

NGC 2655 is a small galaxy.IC 342is one of the brightest two galaxies in theIC 342/Maffei Groupof galaxies. The dwarf irregular galaxyNGC 1569is a magnitude 11.9starburst galaxy, about 11 million light years away.

MS0735.6+7421is a galaxy cluster with aredshiftof 0.216, located 2.6 billion light-years from Earth. It is unique for itsintracluster medium, which emitsx-raysat a very high rate. This galaxy cluster features two cavities 600,000 light-years in diameter, caused by its centralsupermassive black hole, which emits jets of matter. MS0735.6+7421 is one of the largest and most distant examples of this phenomenon.sfnWilkinsDunn2006

Tombaugh 5 is a fairly dim open cluster in Camelopardalis. It has an overall magnitude of 8.4 and is located 5,800 light-years from Earth. It is a Shapley class c and Trumpler class III 1 r cluster, meaning that it is irregularly shaped and appears loose. Though it is detached from the star field, it is not concentrated at its center at all. It has more than 100 stars which do not vary widely in brightness,sfnLevy200589mostly being of the 15th and 16th magnitude.sfnLevy200591
NGC 2146is an 11th magnitude barred spiralstarburst galaxyconspicuously warped by interaction with a neighbour.
MACS0647-JD, one of the possible candidates for the farthest known galaxies in the universe (Redshiftz= 10.7), is also in Camelopardalis.
article.heading: anchorMeteor shower radiantMeteor showers

preblock.preline: The annual May meteor shower Camelopardalids from comet209P/LINEARhave aRadiant (meteor shower)radiantin Camelopardalis.

article.heading: Space exploration
article.paragraph: Thespace probeVoyager 1is moving in the direction of this constellation, though it will not be nearing any of the stars in this constellation for many thousands of years, by which time its power source will be long dead.
article.heading: History

link.target: Image:Sidney Hall - Urania's Mirror - Camelopardalis, Tarandus and Custos Messium.jpg
link.part: Camelopardalis as depicted in ''Urania's Mirror'', a set of constellation cards published in London c.1825. Above it are shown the now-abandoned constellations ofTarandus (constellation)TarandusandCustos Messium.

article.paragraph: Camelopardalis was created byPetrus Planciusin 1613 to represent the animalRebeccarode to marryIsaacinthe Bible.sfnRidpath200192-93One year later,Jakob Bartschfeatured it in his atlas.Johannes Heveliusgave it the official name of "Camelopardus" or "Camelopardalis" because he saw the constellation's many faint stars as the spots of a giraffe.sfnStaal1988241

Part of the constellation was hived off to form the constellation Sciurus Volans, the Flying Squirrel, by William Croswell in 1910. However this was not taken up by later cartographers.cite bookNickKanas2007Star maps: history, artistry, and cartography131https://books.google.com.au/books?idSpringerNew York, New York0-387-71668-8-
article.heading: Visualizations
article.paragraph: H. A. Reyhas suggested an alternative way to connect the stars of Camelopardalis into agiraffefigure.Image:Camelopardalis constellation map visualization.PNGthumb300pxrightDiagram ofH. A. Rey's method of connecting the stars of the constellation Camelopardalis, in order to show a giraffe.clearleft

The giraffe's body consists of the quadrangle of starsAlpha CamelopardalisCam,beta CamelopardalisCam,BE CamelopardalisBE Cam, andGamma CamelopardalisCam: Cam and Cam being of the fourth magnitude. The starsHD 42818(HR 2209) andM CamelopardalisM Camform theheadof the giraffe, and the stars M Cam and Cam form the giraffe's longneck. Stars Cam and7 Camelopardalis7 Camform the giraffe's front leg, andvariable starsBE Cam andCS CamelopardalisCS Camform the giraffe's hind leg.
article.heading: Equivalents
article.paragraph: InChinese astronomy, the stars of Camelopardalis are located within a group of circumpolar stars called thePurple Forbidden Enclosure(Z Wi Yun).
